title: Final Circulating Pressure (FCP)
content: Final Circulating Pressure is the drill pipe pressure you'll maintain once kill weight mud reaches the bit. FCP is lower than ICP because the heavier kill mud has higher friction loss in the drillstring. The formula: FCP = (Kill MW ÷ Current MW) × SCR Pressure. This ratio adjusts the circulating pressure for the new, heavier fluid. During the kill, you transition from ICP to FCP as kill mud fills the drillstring.

formula.equation: FCP (psi) = (Kill MW (ppg) ÷ Current MW (ppg)) × SCR Pressure (psi)

variables.FCP: Final circulating pressure on drill pipe

example.given: Kill MW = 12.0 ppg, Current MW = 11.0 ppg, SCR = 600 psi

mcq.question: Kill MW is 13.0 ppg, current MW is 12.0 ppg, and SCR pressure is 720 psi. What is the FCP?
mcq.explanation: FCP = (13.0 ÷ 12.0) × 720 = 1.083 × 720 = 780 psi. Note that FCP is higher than SCR because kill mud is denser than original mud.

openQuestions: Why is FCP always higher than the original SCR pressure?
Explain why FCP is lower than ICP.

practiceProblems.problem: Kill MW = 11.5 ppg, Current MW = 10.5 ppg, SCR = 550 psi
Kill MW = 14.0 ppg, Current MW = 12.5 ppg, SCR = 800 psi
Kill MW = 10.8 ppg, Current MW = 10.0 ppg, SCR = 500 psi

examTip: Remember: FCP formula uses the RATIO of mud weights multiplied by SCR. Many candidates confuse this with the ICP formula. ICP adds, FCP multiplies a ratio.
